abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Flood Emergency
            Rehabilitation Project for Djibouti were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: it is important
            to entrust implementation of a post-disaster operation to a
            well established agency, with good knowledge of Bank
            procedures and adequate procurement and financial management
            capacity. ADETIP (National Executing Agency for Public Works
            - Agence Djiboutienne d'Execution des Travaux
            d'Interet Public) did a good job in coordinating
            implementation of a large number of components. The lack of
            government reaction to the encroachment on public domain in
            a sensitive area is puzzling and needs to be discussed
            within the country dialogue context. Sooner or later, the
            Government will have to address the problem, hopefully
            before a severe flood. The Bank policy on involuntary
            resettlement is difficult to accept by governments in
            countries where squatters include illegal immigrants from
            neighboring countries. They consider it as too generous and
            are afraid of creating precedents. This is a sensitive issue
            which should be discussed openly with the recipient
            countries. Sustainability of the dike and of the
            surveillance system is a major issue. The Bank hired a
            consultant to review this issue and make appropriate
            recommendations. This was most useful. It is important now
            to sensitize key stakeholders to the findings and
            recommendations of the report. Resources should be made
            available for that purpose.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Additional Credit for the Djibouti
            Flood Emergency Rehabilitation Project (FERP) will help
            finance the costs overruns associated with the
            reconstruction of the Ambouli Dike (the main infrastructure
            to protect the city of Djibouti from further floods) and of
            some of the roads damaged by the floods, and the related
            project management fees of the implementing agency. Because
            of the emergency nature of the FERP, the technical design
            and specifications of the dike were prepared after
            appraisal, and the updated estimated cost for its
            reconstruction has increased significantly. Estimates for
            the road rehabilitation works have also increased, mainly
            because of the increasing oil prices, which contribute
            significantly to the construction costs. About half of the
            roads damaged by the floods and included in the
            Project's original scope of work would not be
            rehabilitated under the project because of estimated cost overruns.

            Project : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
In anticipation of minor relocation and
            resettlement risks as a result of the Djibouti Flood
            Emergency Rehabilitation Project (Oued Rehabilitation
            Project), the World Bank had requested that the protection
            dyke design and the widening/leveling of the Oued riverbed,
            avoid - to the maximum extent possible - the relocation of
            housing structures, and/or economic activities, and that the
            resettlement compensation plan be designed to mitigate its
            effects, especially among vulnerable populations. The
            government decided to relocate the population of the Ambouli
            Oued to Cite Gargaar not only because of project activities
            but also for their own security as they are periodically
            victimized by flooding. This report aims to ensure that this
            population's standard of living will be improved as it
            ensures the integration of the newly resettled families
            within existing socio-economic structures, and activities.
            This report identifies 127 affected households inhabiting
            105 structures in the Ambouli Oued area. Although among them
            are non-nationals, this group may be accorded compensation
            so they can be relocated to a place of their choosing. The
            report describes the bolstering of the existing regulatory
            and legal framework for resettlement, the mechanisms for
            public consultation, the two compensation options (land or
            monthly payments) for land, transport assistance,
            construction of housing assistance, commercial
            infrastructure supports (potable water and electricity,
            roads, markets, etc.) and social and educational
            infrastructure (health centers, community development
            centers, police stations, etc.).

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Flood Emergency
            Rehabilitation Project is to rehabilitate the economic, and
            social infrastructure damaged by the April 2004 floods in
            Djibouti. The main benefits would be the restoration of
            services, through the rehabilitation of roads, bridges,
            flood control works, health centers, and schools. Despite
            its benefits, possible risks include: a) institutional
            overlap and lack of coordination in the Ambouli Oued
            rehabilitation project among government ministries, and
            donor agencies, but mitigation measures include expansion of
            the Djiboutian Agency for Implementation of Publics Works -
            ADETIP - through the steering committee to ensure government
            coordination among line ministries and agencies, and,
            coordination with th European Union (EU), the United Nations
            Development Programme (UNDP) and the African Development
            Bank (AfDB); b) minor relocation and resettlement risks as a
            result of the Oued rehabilitation project; mitigation
            includes that as a condition for the no-objection to proceed
            with the Oued rehabilitation component, the Bank requested
            that the protection dyke design and the widening/leveling of
            the Oued riverbed, avoid - to the maximum extent possible -
            the relocation of housing structures, and/or economic
            activities, and that a resettlement compensation plan be
            designed appropriately; c) the selling by flood victims of
            their lands and houses prompted the following mitigation
            measures: a rapid socio-economic study will be conducted to
            determine the extent of flood victims' willingness to
            remain in place, although the proximity to Port Doraleh, and
            its benefiting from several donor-financed projects, makes
            it a more viable, livable place. ADETIP will also ensure the
            integration of newly resettled families within existing
            socio-economic structures, and activities.
